messages.text:
Hey guys, so the Codecov repo says that to use it with Travis, one just needs to add:
```after_success:
- julia -e 'using Pkg; cd(Pkg.dir("MyPkg")); Pkg.add("Coverage"); using Coverage; Codecov.submit(Codecov.process_folder())'```
At the end of the yml file. How do we do it on GitHub Actions?

elements.text: Hey guys, so the Codecov repo says that to use it with Travis, one just needs to add:

after_success:
- julia -e 'using Pkg; cd(Pkg.dir("MyPkg")); Pkg.add("Coverage"); using Coverage; Codecov.submit(Codecov.process_folder())'
At the end of the yml file. How do we do it on GitHub Actions?

messages.text: This is what I recommend for Codecov in GitHub Actions:

elements.text: This is what I recommend for Codecov in GitHub Actions:

messages.text:
```- uses: julia-actions/julia-buildpkg@v1
- uses: julia-actions/julia-runtest@v1
- uses: julia-actions/julia-processcoverage@v1
- uses: codecov/codecov-action@v1
  with:
    file: <http://lcov.info|lcov.info>```

elements.text:
- uses: julia-actions/julia-buildpkg@v1
- uses: julia-actions/julia-runtest@v1
- uses: julia-actions/julia-processcoverage@v1
- uses: codecov/codecov-action@v1
  with:

messages.text:
When you specify `ubuntu-latest` and  arch `x86` in the `matrix` and use

```      - uses: julia-actions/setup-julia@latest
        with:
          version: ${{ matrix.version }}
          arch: ${{ matrix.arch }}```
It actually doesn't pull in a VM with  arch `x86`, but rather the Julia `x86` arch binaries, right?

The reason I ask.  I'm testing `HDF5_jll` and I requested ubuntu on x86, but the build failed because  we  longer   ship BB artifacts for x86 <https://github.com/JuliaBinaryWrappers/HDF5_jll.jl/blob/main/Artifacts.toml>    in v1.12. For some reason the build process tried to pull in v1.12 of HDF5_jll, instead of v1.10.5, which does support x86.

messages.text: reminder of maintenance of macOS runners this week :point_up:

elements.text:
GitHub Actions hosted runners for macOS may experience longer wait times during the week of December 14.

During the week of December 14-18, GitHub will be performing scheduled maintenance on one of our datacenters that may result in longer than normal wait times for GitHub-hosted macOS runners: macos-latest, macos-10.14, or macos-10.15. In some cases, it may be possible that jobs will time out or be cancelled, and will need to be restarted.
reminder of maintenance of macOS runners this week

messages.text:
If you need a backup of their repo data, including issues, prs etc, I wrote a short action to help with that: <https://github.com/SaschaMann/restic-action>

It's just a thin wrapper over github-backup and restic, so it works with S3, B2,  and like 30 other cloud storage services.

I haven't written docs yet (and I probably won't) but you should only have to change these lines to configure it: <https://github.com/SaschaMann/restic-action/blob/87f2240709e7b4d91c86d983146bea553dc89c58/.github/workflows/backup.yml#L29-L33>

elements.text: If you need a backup of their repo data, including issues, prs etc, I wrote a short action to help with that:

messages.text: I agree with <@UBVE598BC> and <@U67D54KS8> that the output of `julia --version` (`julia version 1.7.0-DEV`) is not specific enough.

The times are:
- `julia --version` takes 0.021 seconds
- `julia -e 'println(Base.VERSION)'` takes 0.599 seconds
- `julia -e 'import InteractiveUtils; InteractiveUtils.versioninfo()'` takes 1.155 seconds
<@U6C5KSWAC> What do you think about doing `julia -e 'println(Base.VERSION)'` as a default?

elements.text: What do you think about doing

messages.text:
The new times are:
- `julia --compile=min -O0 -e 'println(Base.VERSION)'` takes 0.303 seconds
- `julia --compile=min -O0 -e 'import InteractiveUtils; InteractiveUtils.versioninfo()'` takes 0.655 seconds
`julia --version` versus `julia --compile=min -O0 --version` are the same, which makes sense. The times for that range from 0.020 seconds to 0.023 seconds.

messages.text:
maybe it's common knowledge, but you can do stuff like
```      - name: Hello World
        shell: julia {0}
        run: |
          println("Hello World!")```
which sometimes may simplify things a bit (you can write a proper Julia script across multiple lines instead of cramming everything into a single-line string)

messages.text:
I am improving :chainrules:  reverse dependency integration tests actions. And currently when such a action errors due to incompatibility it shows as a failure, but I want that to show as a pass. Since it means we didn't break any SemVer promises.
I think I can make it work by running the resolver in a seperate step and then telling GHA that if that step fails then the job has succeeded?

elements.text:
reverse dependency integration tests actions. And currently when such a action errors due to incompatibility it shows as a failure, but I want that to show as a pass. Since it means we didn't break any SemVer promises.
I think I can make it work by running the resolver in a seperate step and then telling GHA that if that step fails then the job has succeeded?

messages.text: I'm not sure I understand: step failing -> success, step passing -> failure?

messages.text:
Step 1: check compatible. Basically by running `pkg"dev upstream" and see if Julia exits with a failure. If it does then can report pass, since SemVer is being followed.

Step 2 run downstream packages tests. If they pass then pass if the fail ten fail

messages.text: <https://docs.github.com/en/actions/reference/workflow-syntax-for-github-actions#using-a-specific-shell> looks like `sh` is a valid shell.  *Edit*: not on Windows :persevere:
alternative: use `julia` as shell and everybody is happy :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: as shell and everybody is happy

messages.text: opened and issue: <https://github.com/julia-actions/julia-runtest/issues/35>
I guess I could have just opened the PR, but I'll do that if there is consensus :sweat_smile:
